DataElement.preferredName: Sequence Analysis Indexed Sequencing Other Specify
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of sequencing method which is different than the one(s) previously specified used to add a unique identifier sequence to samples during library preparation allowing multiple libraries to be pooled and processed together.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The determination of the sequence of component residues in a macromolecule, e.g. amino acids in a protein or nucleotide bases in DNA/RNA or the computational analysis performed to determine the similarities between nonidentical proteins or molecules of DNA or RNA._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._A sequencing method that involves the addition of a unique identifier called an index sequence to samples during library preparation. This allows multiple libraries to be pooled and processed together.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The determination of the sequence of component residues in a macromolecule, e.g. amino acids in a protein or nucleotide bases in DNA/RNA or the computational analysis performed to determine the similarities between nonidentical proteins or molecules of DNA or RNA.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the sequence of component residues in a macromolecule, e.g. amino acids in a protein or nucleotide bases in DNA/RNA or the computational analysis performed to determine the similarities between nonidentical proteins or molecules of DNA or RNA.

Property.preferredDefinition: A sequencing method that involves the addition of a unique identifier called an index sequence to samples during library preparation. This allows multiple libraries to be pooled and processed together.

Concepts.definition: A sequencing method that involves the addition of a unique identifier called an index sequence to samples during library preparation. This allows multiple libraries to be pooled and processed together.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.
